title: Object ID: 1967.06.209
text:
Object Name: Miniature Bowl


Type: Unknown Plainware




Time Period: AD 200 – 1250


Donor: Robert Willis Sheriff



Miniature ceramic vessels like this one are not uncommon at prehistoric sites in the Southwest. Archaeologists have a variety of hypotheses to explain the presence of these vessels, but their purpose remains elusive. What do you think they were used for?

title: Object ID: 1969.17.02
text:
Object Name: Jar


Type: Three Circle Neckcoiled




Time Period: AD 800 – 1000


Donor: Edna Hayes




Object ID: 1969.17.02



Braided handles like the one seen on this Mogollon jar are difficult to execute. The potter had to remove the air pockets in between the coils to prevent the handles from breaking during firing. This is difficult to do without accidentally pressing the individual coils together to form one larger coil.

title: Object ID: 2015.4.469
text:
Object Name: Vessel


Type: Wedding Vessel




Time Period: Contemporary


Artist: Stella Teller




Donor: Phillip L. Boucher


Object ID: 2015.4.469



The body of the vessel is white and a stairstep motif with geometric forms are painted on both faces. The rims have a thin painted black border, The handle has a curved line with dots. The artist signed the base, “Stella Teller Isleta N. Mex.”

title: Object ID: XXXX.XX.XX
text:
Collection: Boucher Collection


Object ID (from table): 2015.04.469




Culture (UDF1): Isleta


Object Name: Vessel




Other Name: NA


Rec From: Phillip L. Boucher




UDF2: Stella Teller


UDF3: Phillip L. Boucher



UDF21: Polychromatic greenware vessel with two spouts and a handle connecting the spouts. The body of the vessel is white and a stairstep motif with geometric forms are painted on both faces. The rims have a thin painted black border, The handle has a curved line with dots. The artist signed the base, “Stella Teller Isleta N. Mex.” Owner’s Notes: White greenware Wedding Vase with parrot motif, red inside of spouts with black rims. Stella Teller, early work Acquired from The Adobe Gallery, Old Town, Albuquerque, NM No date or price of purchase was given.













Condition Information
Maintenance Note: The vessel should be kept at a stable temperature and a relative humidity between 40% and 60%. The owner’s records indicate this is greenware. Because of this the vessel should be handled carfully and big changes in humidity must be avoided. This clay has not been fired. It is not as strong as ceramics and it will be more prone to absorb moisture.
Notes: There are no appraiser’s notes for this vessel. The notes of the previous owner have been included.
Condition: Excellent
Condition Notes: The vessel is in excellent condition with no visible surface or structural flaws.
